Have you ever been here?

Posted by Jeremy Miller on January 12, 2007

I'm only an observer, thank goodness, but I've been there too.  One of the best parts of being a consultant is limited "opportunities" for doing support. 

 

Irate Person:  Fix the problem in production now!

Dev:  Ok, can I get access to the production server?

Irate Person:  No!

Dev:  Ok, so what was it that you were doing when the problem occurred?

Irate Person:  I don't know, just fix it! 

Dev:  …sinking feeling in the pit of your stomach — unless you left a back door open for exactly this case, even though you know that you shouldn't have

About Jeremy Miller

Jeremy is the Chief Software Architect at Dovetail Software, the coolest ISV in Austin. Jeremy began his IT career writing "Shadow IT" applications to automate his engineering documentation, then wandered into software development because it looked like more fun. Jeremy is the author of the open source StructureMap tool for Dependency Injection with .Net, StoryTeller for supercharged acceptance testing in .Net, and one of the principal developers behind FubuMVC. Jeremy's thoughts on all things software can be found at The Shade Tree Developer at http://codebetter.com/jeremymiller.

eXtreme Tuesday Club in New York →
  • http://codebetter.com/blogs/eric.wise Eric Wise

    I wouldn’t excel in that environ. I’d ask the customer at that point if they could fix the radio in my car, without seeing or touching the car.

  • http://codebetter.com/blogs/jeremy.miller jmiller

    You’re not the only one, Eric. The biggest problem with an environment like that is the supreme temptation to break the “rules” just to get something done. Once you disregard the “rules” you’re effectively lawless.

  • http://www.ayende.com/Blog/ Ayende Rahien

    @Eric,
    Great analogy.
    That is a very bad place to be in.
    I had similar conflicts in the past, not just in development. The way I solved it is always jumping two or more levels up, going to someone that _does_ have the authority to do something about it.
    Then again, I am not easily shouted at.

  • http://blog.kapenilattex.com Jon Limjap

    That sucks, and it has happened to me too.

    What I usually tell the client is to send me a screenshot of where the problem occurs, but if they don’t know (and don’t want to be told) how to get a screenshot, then I’ll just tell my supervisor that I’m dealing with an a_hole and we need to elevate the problem somewhere.

    It’s difficult to help people who don’t want to help you help them.

  • Edward

    I agree, great analogy. I find it very funny that back when I worked on helpdesk, 5+ years ago, that almost every analogy I used was car related!

    A common one was tyres = software.
    “If a tyre blows, it doesn’t mean that the car is faulty – you simply replace(reinstall) the tyre and continue driving.”

    Lego was my other favourite analogy. I would describe a PC as a Lego model, where everything just fits together. It was funny when I looked at my screen one day, having used this one, to see that the customer’s surname was Leggo!
